results.title: Prisoners of chance
results.creator_credit: Vitascope Productions, FilmFair Communications, Thom Eberhardt and Marc Stirdivant
results.brief_description: Presents dramatized re-enactments of three case studies of teenage pregnancies: a girl who gives up her baby for adoption when she realizes she cannot cope; a girl who lives with her parents after the birth; and a couple who marries after the girl becomes pregnant. De-romanticises the notion of “Having a baby” by pointing out some commo problems of teenage pregnancies.

results.title: Prisoners
results.creator_credit: Prisoners' Action Group, Tony Green and Mark Stiles
results.brief_description: Uses an innovative mix of interviews, photographs and sketches combined with comprehensive statistical information, to provide a profile on prisoners in New South Wales. Shows who goes to prison, why, and what happens to them inside the gaols. Interviews with ex-prisoners and their families demonstrate the futility of prisons as an answer to social problems. Touches on the destructive fires at Bathurst Jail and the reprisals carried out on prisoners before their transfer.

results.title: Prisoner or patient
results.brief_description: The debate continues: are those guilty of grotesque crimes mentally disturbed or just evil? Should they be locked up and punished, or treated for illness? This documentary examines what happens to thousands of inadequate and sick offenders. It shows how the system works in Britain from courtroom to institution.

results.title: Prisoner of the mountains = Kavkazsky Plennik
results.creator_credit: Karavan, BG Productions, Boris Giller and Sergei Bodrov
results.brief_description: By all appearances, ‘Prisoner of the Mountains’ can easily be branded a film about the conflict in Chechnya. In fact, it was conceived well before the beginning of the war and has a short story by Leo Tolstoy, ‘Prisoner of the Caucasus’, as its basis. As the war rages in the Caucasus, young recruit Vania (Sergei Bodrov, Jr.) is sent off to the front, where he befriends a wily and experienced soldier, Sasha (Oleg Menshikov). During an ambush, the pair is captured by Muslims forces and taken prisoner to a mountain village. The leader - Abdel Murat (Djemal Sikharulidze), intends to use the soldiers as exchange currency against his son, held prisoner by the Russian army. As their stay in the village extends, a mutual understanding develops between Vania and Abdel Murat as well as a tender friendship with his daughter. However, Sasha plots to use this new found understanding as a means for achieving freedom. ‘Prisoner of the Mountains’ is a powerful anti-war fable exploring the universal themes of human friendship overcoming, for a luminous moment, the barriers of language, religion, culture and other physical and mental borders. Filmed on location in Daghestan, ‘Prisoner of the Mountains’ was cast mostly with local villager. This visual feast set among stunning mountainous landscape garnered a scoop of awards and nominations, including Best Foreign Film Oscar Nomination (1996) and the Cannes Film Festival Award (1996). In Russian with English subtitles.

results.title: Prisoner of St Petersburg
results.creator_credit: Seon Films, Panorama Films, Daniel Scharf, Klaus Sunger and Ian Pringle
results.brief_description: Noah Taylor is Jack, a young man who is obsessed by the lives of the great Russian writers. He wanders through a dreamscape in which reality entwines with characters from Dostoevsky, Tolstoy and Gogol. Penniless in a cold and bleak West Berlin, he falls in love with Elena, (Solveig Dommartin), who in his fevered imagination comes to represent Dostoevsky’s pure and ill-treated Sasha. Over the course of a magical night in Berlin, Jack, Elena and her friend Johanna search the alleys and autobahns of Berlin seeking love, solace and the promise of redemption. This idosyncratic and romantic Australian film is a lyrical celebration of human contact and communion.

results.title: Prison on fire
results.creator_credit: Cinema City Film Production, Catherine Chang, Karl Maka and Ringo Lam
results.brief_description: After accidentally committing a murder, a young advertising executive is sentenced to three years in prison. His clean looks and straight-forward honesty with the prison staff make him a target for the various triad factions at work in the institution, until he forms an alliance with an older prisoner who knows the ins and outs of the system. Less an action film than a drama in the prison film genre, “Prison on fire” explores themes of honour, loyalty and friendship, capturing the bleakness and despair of prison life through the drab, claustrophobic colour scheme and absence of music. Lam’s portrayal of a Chinese prison eschews the usual prison film cliches, focusing instead on how the prison environment brings out the worst in people. Cast includes Chow Yun-Fat, Tony Leung and Roy Cheung. In Cantonese with English subtitles.
